mods.abstract: View of the Acme Moving & Storage Co. storefront on Second Avenue. A sign for the company is hanging from the front a building. Cars and a truck are parked on the street in front of the entrance. Part of the sign for Newt Billings Moving & Storage Co. is visible above the storefront of the building on the right. An area of the street is blocked off near the entrances to the buildings.

The C.B. Pearce & Co. building, located at 172 Second Avenue, is a three-story, Italianate style brick building with one bay. The façade has brick corbeling and a cornice with brackets and endcaps near the roofline. The second and third-story rounded windows have Italianate style molding around and arched stone sills with keystones. John S. Heart owned the lot from 1866-1889 before Charles’s Nelson (owner of 134-136 Second Avenue) purchased it. The building was likely constructed around 1885, before the property transfer. Liquor dealers C.B. Pearce & Co. began leasing the space in 1890. Previous occupants include Rich Printing Co., Moneyweight Scale Co., Bell, Long & Geistman, and Acme Moving & Storage Co. The Brown & Farrell Hardware/M.E. Derryberry building, located at 170 Second Avenue, is a three-story, Commercial style brick building constructed around 1885. The Doric wall pilasters on the upper floors run up to the cornice. The storefront has a stringcourse running the width of the building. Arched brickwork surrounds each of the windows on the second and third floors. The property was deeded to William A. Goodwyn in 1883. Brown & Farrell Hardware began occupying the space in 1890. Other previous occupants include W. A. Case & Son Mfg. Co. and Newt Billings Moving & Storage Co., From 1914 to 1970, the M.E. Derryberry family owned the building. Previous addresses for the building include 11, 22, and 24 South Market Street.
